Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Refugees, Labor Markets and Urban Revitalization

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This doctoral dissertation project examines the role of refugee women in the revitalization of American cities. The doctoral student will examine how urban revitalization and gentrification in U.S. cities are linked to both refugee women's direct labor in these resettlement cities and the economic pulse generated by remittance flows from the labor of women relatives living in displacement cities in intermediary countries. The project will directly benefit society by investigating the relationship between refugee women and urban economic development in the U.S. It will also promote teaching, learning, and knowledge-sharing between diverse groups through collaborative partnerships with refugee community organizations. Project findings will be shared with municipal governments and nonprofit refugee service organizations to contribute to the formulation of more effective, inclusive, and equitable refugee resettlement policies.

This dissertation project investigates how refugee women's labor and translocal linkages contribute to urban revitalization and gentrification in the U.S. through their subsidization of urban landscape transformation. The project's central questions are: (1) How does the focus on immediate and "full" employment by refugee resettlement institutions shape refugee women's practices of unpaid labor in their resettlement community? (2) How do refugee women in third country locations support refugees based in the U.S.? (3) In what ways do refugee women's translocal linkages, unpaid labor, and social reproduction practices subsidize urban revitalization and facilitate gentrification in their resettlement community in the U.S.? Using a variety of qualitative methodologies such as interviews, a survey, extended observation, photovoice, and textual analysis to investigate these questions via a case study of Rohingya refugees in the rapidly gentrifying city of Aurora, Colorado as well as Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia, a displacement site from which many Aurora-based refugees come. This Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement award will provide support to enable a promising student to establish an academic research career.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Drawing on 18 months of ethnographic fieldwork with Rohingya and Myanmar Muslim refugees and migrants in Kuala Lumpur, Malaysia and Aurora, Colorado, this research project produced two key outcomes that contribute to scholarly knowledge about the relationship between refugee work and economic development, as well as generating broader impacts for society. First, findings complicate conventional understandings of remittances, which are broadly understood to flow from wealthier people and places to poorer ones. In the case of Rohingya and Myanmar Muslim refugees in Aurora, resources and aid flow from poorer places to wealthier cities in the United States. Many refugees resettled in Aurora depended on material aid and care work from women relatives in Malaysia and Myanmar because wages and benefits were insufficient to survive. By reducing social benefits for refugees, municipal government downloads the full cost of caring for refugees onto refugees themselves, allowing the city to channel funds to other development projects. At the same time, private companies benefit from refugees’ vulnerability and limited positioning in local labor markets, expanding their business and increasing profits as resettled refugees continue to depend on family members to supplement low wages and inconsistent paychecks. In one case, a local pallett company reduced turnover by over 270% and boosted profits after replacing Latino workers with Burmese-speaking refugees. These findings contributed to new understandings of the relational link between between refugees’ home places in Southeast Asia and economic growth wealthier cities of the so-called Global North.

 

Second, this project created broader social impacts by directly benefiting Rohingya and Myanmar Muslim women through the use of feminist participatory methods, including Theatre of the Oppressed, which created space for beneficial peer support and community-building among often-isolated and marginalized people. Research findings and policy recommendations were also shared with local nonprofit service organizations and the city of Aurora’s Natural Helpers program director. The co-PI recommends that refugee service organizations make connections with alternative employers in Denver, such as artisanal clothing makers and furniture companies, to offer resettled refugees options for a living wage and stable employment outside meatpacking and manufacturing plants. The co-PI also recommends that the city pay refugees and immigrants for their volunteer social work. Taken together, project findings demonstrate the ineluctable link between refugee work, relational practices of mutual aid, and wider capitalist development across multiple scales.
